claim: If video recordings of lectures are provided, nothing in particular happens to class attendance.

supporting.text: Studies show that providing video recordings of lectures does not significantly impact attendance rates, as students still value in-person interaction and immediate feedback.

attacks.text: Studies show that providing video recordings of lectures does not significantly impact attendance rates, as students still value in-person interaction and immediate feedback.
Some studies indicate that providing lecture recordings can lead to a decline in attendance, as students may prioritize convenience over in-person engagement.
The decline in attendance due to lecture recordings is often temporary, as students eventually recognize the benefits of in-person participation for deeper learning.
The impact of lecture recordings on attendance varies by subject and teaching style, making broad generalizations unreliable.
Even with subject variability, meta-analyses show no consistent negative effect of lecture recordings on attendance across disciplines.

supporting.text: Empirical data from universities indicates that class attendance remains stable when lecture recordings are available, as many students prefer the structured learning environment of physical classrooms.

attacks.text: Empirical data from universities indicates that class attendance remains stable when lecture recordings are available, as many students prefer the structured learning environment of physical classrooms.
Studies show that attendance drops significantly when recordings are available, as students prioritize flexibility over in-person attendance.
The drop in attendance is often temporary, as students later realize the value of in-person interaction and return to classrooms.
The preference for physical classrooms varies by subject; attendance remains stable in discussion-heavy courses but drops in lecture-heavy ones.
Even in lecture-heavy courses, attendance stabilizes once students adapt to blended learning methods.

supporting.text: Research suggests that students who attend lectures in person perform better academically, which discourages reliance solely on video recordings and maintains attendance levels.

attacks.text: Research suggests that students who attend lectures in person perform better academically, which discourages reliance solely on video recordings and maintains attendance levels.
Studies show that many students prefer the flexibility of video recordings, leading to decreased in-person attendance despite potential academic benefits.
The correlation between in-person attendance and academic performance may be influenced by self-selection bias, as motivated students are more likely to attend lectures regardless of format.
Some institutions report no significant change in attendance after introducing video recordings, suggesting that student habits vary widely by context.
In cases where attendance remains stable, it may be due to mandatory attendance policies rather than student preference for in-person learning.

supporting.text: Lecture recordings are often used as supplementary resources rather than replacements for attendance, as they lack opportunities for real-time discussion and engagement.

attacks.text: Lecture recordings are often used as supplementary resources rather than replacements for attendance, as they lack opportunities for real-time discussion and engagement.
Studies show that when lecture recordings are available, a significant portion of students skip live lectures, relying solely on recordings.
The students who skip live lectures often perform worse in assessments, indicating that recordings alone are insufficient for learning.
Lecture recordings can be paused and rewatched, which may enhance understanding and compensate for missing live discussions.
Passive watching of recordings without active engagement (e.g., asking questions) leads to lower retention rates compared to live lectures.

supporting.text: Institutions that provide lecture recordings report no substantial decline in attendance, as students recognize the benefits of active participation and networking in live sessions.

attacks.text: Institutions that provide lecture recordings report no substantial decline in attendance, as students recognize the benefits of active participation and networking in live sessions.
Studies show that when lecture recordings are available, a significant portion of students skip live classes, relying on recordings instead.
The studies showing attendance decline often fail to account for students who skip classes for reasons unrelated to recordings, such as illness or scheduling conflicts.
Lecture recordings can lead to passive learning habits, where students delay watching lectures and cram before exams, reducing engagement.
Many students use recordings to reinforce learning by revisiting complex topics, which enhances understanding and exam performance.
